results.title: The Living tundra
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock, British Broadcasting Corporation and British Petroleum
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Web of life”.
A study of the ecology of the Alaskan tundra, showing it in winter when it is barren and locked in snow and ice, and in spring when flocks of wild fowl fly in and the tundra becomes covered in flowers.

results.title: Lifetimes of change: development and growth
results.creator_credit: Australian Academy of Science and Educational Media International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Web of life”.
Shows the changes that take place within the lifetimes of individual organisms. Illustrates the ideas of birth, growth, change and decay by using three examples from the natural world: toadstools, frogs and flowering plants. Also notes the main changes in structure and in behaviour that distinguish a human lifetime. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Desert hopping mouse
results.creator_credit: David Corke and Educational Media International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Web of life”.
Focuses on the spinifex hopping mouse of inland Australia to illustrate the many features it possesses which enable it to survive in what appears to be an extremely hostile environment. Also shows its daily activities, its methods of reproduction and the ways in which these may change with the seasons or from year to year. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.brief_description: Introduces various recreational sports, including golf, ten-pin bowling, badminton, tennis and archery. Includes ideas on the multi-purpose use of facilities.

results.title: Life. Be in it
results.creator_credit: Victorian Department of Youth, Sport and Recreation
results.brief_description: Phillip Adams conceived and developed the “Life Be In It” advertising campaign aimed at encouraging the community to become more involved in physical activity and recreation. Includes examples of television commercials featuring characters such as Norm, the average all-round armchair sportsman.

results.title: Life in North China
results.brief_description: The mountains of Manchuria are dotted with rural communes - farm villages operating as production teams, working the land on a collective basis. While many of the farming techniques are primitive, the people are building towards an efficient tomorrow by operating small basic industries. Some are constructing their own chemical fertiliser plants and agricultural colleges. Their spirit of self-sufficiency and co-operation has its parallel in the urban industrial centres, where factory workers often build their own essential manufacturing equipment, and all major decisions in the plant are made by a committee of workers, technicians, and management officers. At harvest time, thousands of teachers, students and workers leave the cities to work beside their countrymen in the fields. Later, on National Liberation Day, these two life-styles merge again in celebration of their growing nation.

results.title: Life in China: mill worker's family
results.creator_credit: Richard Sanderson and Department of Photography and Cinema, Ohio State University
results.brief_description: One of a series of films about contemporary life in Mainland China. Reveals the family life of a skilled cotton-mill worker, his wife, son and grandmother. The family is seen at work, at home, at study and enjoying leisure as a three generation family on their duty off in Peking’s Park.

results.title: Life goes on
results.creator_credit: Angela Pope, John Furse and Melrose Productions
results.brief_description: Tells the story of Peggy and George, an elderly couple, who retire with what they think is a reasonable income. But a few years later inflation has taken its toll and they find themselves short of money.

results.title: Lichfield: a symphony in stone
results.brief_description: A study of Lichfield Cathedral, famous for its three spires, the central one of which was ruined in the Civil War, but afterwards restored. Illistrates archetecture, constructional details, carving and statues of the Cathedral.

results.title: Libraries without bars
results.brief_description: Shows modern improvements being made in Japanese libraries to stimulate interest in reading and to encourage appreciation of art, music and literature. Special aspects of the work of these libraries include film programs, radio listening, children’s Saturday afternoon film programs, music rooms and collections of recorded music, art exhibitions, puppet plays, bookmobile services in country districts and many other activities.
